Video.Text: Here's a video about spending one-on-one time with your child!

Set of messages 1.Message: One-on-One Time with your children is free and fun. It makes children feel loved and secure, and shows them that they are important. It also increases their confidence and self-esteem!
Set of messages 1.Interaction message: Would you like to learn more?
Set of messages 1.Message for negative answer: That's okay! You can always type "Help" whenever you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your child. Chat to you later!

List of tips.Message: Here are 6 tips to make One-on-One Time with your child a success:

Option 1: Spend at least five minutes wi.Message:
1. Spend at least five minutes with each child
Even 5 minutes a day of quality time  makes a big difference. If you have more than one child, you can take turns or let each child choose an activity. It can be at the same time each day so your children look forward to it.

Option 2: Give your child your full atte.Message:
2. Give your child your full attention
Make sure you will not be interrupted. Switch off the TV and put your phone on silent. It will show your child, they are important.

Option 3: Let your child choose the acti.Message 1:
3. Let your child choose the activity
Ask your child what they would like to do. You can say, "I have 5 minutes to spend One-on-One Time with you, what would you like to do?
Option 3: Let your child choose the acti.Message 2: Choosing builds their self confidence. If they want to do something that isnâ€™t OK with COVID-19 rules, then this is a chance to talk with them about this.
Option 3: Let your child choose the acti.Message 3: If your child cannot think of anything, you can give them a choice of a couple things that you know they like.

Option 4: Follow your child's lead.Message:
4. Follow your child's lead
Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative.

Option 5: Use words to describe what you.Message:
5. Use words to describe what your child is doing
Listening to your child is more important than talking to them at this time. If you do talk you should describe what your child is doing. Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening!

Option 6: Have fun!.Message:
6. Have fun!
One-on-One Time with your child can be fun for you, too! You might even find that you feel less stressed after playing with your child.
